section.title: Query builders at a glance
section.para: The query builders are a set of PHP classes which generate SQL. These classes contain methods which manipulate the final output, making it possible to easily tailor a query dynamically without fear of malformed SQL or compromised security.
The classes, starting with Db_Query_* are responsible for one type of query each: SELECT ( Db_Query_Select), INSERT (Db_Query_Insert), UPDATE (Db_Query_Update) and DELETE (Db_Query_Delete)
The benefits of using query builders are several:

listitem.para: Automatic escaping and protection from SQL injection attacks and other SQL-vulnerabilities.
You can easily manipulate queries before executing them, no need to perform complex string building or to call escaping methods all the time.
Almost no risk of executing malformed SQL.

section.para: A few drawbacks:

listitem.para: A small loss of performance when generating the queries.
The query builders cannot create all types of SQL.

section.title: Generic Usage
section.para: The different query builders work very alike, they differ in a few key points in the same way that the different query types differ between each other.

section.title: Getting a query builder object
section.para: To get a query builder object, you call a specific method on the Db_Connection object(s):

section.title: SELECT query builder object
section.para: The $columns parameter is there for selecting special columns that might not be bound to a special table, or some other thing that should be placed in the SELECT part of the query.
(If a column is located in a table which is to be included, use the Db_Query_Select->from to select the columns, then they will be aliased properly.)

section.title: INSERT query builder object
section.para: The Db_Connection->insert method requires a table name which would be the name of the table to insert data into. If the $data is specified, the row will be inserted with the supplied data and a boolean value will be returned (true equals a successful query).

section.title: UPDATE query builder object
section.para: Like the Db_Connection->insert this method has two variants: one to create a query object and another to create the object, populate it the supplied data and finally execute the query and returning the results. Both variants uses $data to populate the update object, sending it to Db_Query_Update->set.

The $conditions array is sent to the Db_Query_Update->where method. But if you require some fancy conditions, it might not be satisfactory — it would be better to use the first variant of Db_Connection->update and then apply them using Db_Query->where (which Db_Query_Update has inherited).

section.title: DELETE query builder object
section.para: As you probably already guessed, the first variant is for creating the query object and the second is to execute the query directly. $table is the table name of the table to delete rows from and $conditions work in the same way as the $conditions parameter of Db_Connection->update.
$table can also be an array, if you want to do a multi-table delete. If the keys are non-numeric, they will be used as aliases for the table name which is stored in the value.

warning.para: If you specify multiple tables, make sure that the $conditions parameter reference the correct table if several tables has the same column names.

section.title: Getting the generated SQL before it is sent to the database
section.para: All the Query builders have the Db_Query->getSQL() method, making it easy to either debug your queries or to create eg. UNIONs:

example.title: Creating an UNION query from two Db_Query_Select objects

section.title: Method chaining
section.para: All the Query builders can use method chaining. They also return the object instance in almost all cases, except when the method returns the return value of the query (or some other "special" method).

example.title: Method Chaining with the Query builders

section.title: The FROM part
section.para: The one call that is required to be made to a Db_Query_Select object is a call to Db_Query_Select->from, to specify from which table to fetch the data.

The $tables parameter is very versatile, it can be just contain a string with the table name — making it generate an "anonymous" alias (internally it names them using the "t" prefix and then a number). Or it can contain an array with several table names, aliasing all with different "anonymous" aliases.

example.title: Simple Db_Query_Select->from usage

section.para: But it can also take an array with non-numeric keys as a parameter. This makes it alias the values as the key names:

example.title: Specifying custom aliases using Db_Query_Select->from

section.para: Finally you can replace the table names with instances of Db_Query_Select to make them subqueries:

example.title: Using subqueries with Db_Query_Select->from

section.para: The second parameter of Db_Query_Select->from, $columns, is used to control which columns to fetch from the database. Limiting the number of columns which are fetched from the database increases performance, especially when joining other tables which you only filter by (or when using subqueries). All the column names are prefixed by the table name, making them unambiguous.

If the second parameter is an array, all the non-numeric keys are used as aliases for the columns (and the alias will be the name to refer to the property which contains the column data) — the numeric keys will not get any aliases (which means that they will get the column name as the property name).
Essentially, the $columns parameter is sent to the Db_Query_Select->columns method. See its behaviour for more in-depth information.

example.title: Choosing which columns to fetch with Db_Query_Select->from

section.para: If two tables are specified in the $tables array, both will have the columns specified in $columns SELECTed.

section.title: No escape() combined with Db_Query_Select->from
section.para: If Db_Query->escape is set to false, then the $columns parameter won't be escaped, just like the Db_Query_Select->column works when escaping is turned off.

section.title: Selecting additional columns
section.para: To select extra columns, which might not be bound to a specific table or columns that needs to be added later in the execution (to a table which already have been used in Db_Query_Select->from), you use Db_Query_Select->column:

The first parameter $columns contains columns which will be appended to the SELECT part of the query. If $columns is a string, it will just be identifier protected and then appended. And if it is an array, the non-numeric keys will be used as aliases for the columns.

The $table parameter is the name of the table from which the columns should be selected. This is used to prevent unambiguous column names inside the SELECT. If it is non-empty, this table name will be prepended to all the specified columns (with a dot in between). The $table will also be identifier protected.
$table_is_aliased controls whether the Database Prefix will be prepended to $table before it is added to the query. This is used when you refer to columns from eg. an alias.

section.title: No escape() and column()
section.para: If escape is set to false the columns won't be identifier protected. The aliases will still be identifier protected even if the columns themselves are not.

example.title: Counting the number of rows in a table

section.title: Joining tables (JOIN)
section.para: To join another table to the tables you already have specified with Db_Query_Select->from, use Db_Query_Select->join:

The first parameter is the table name to join, which can be without alias, with alias (in an array where the alias is key, only the first key=>value pair will be joined) and a subquery (just replace the string with the variable containing the subquery).

The second parameter, $condition, is as it sounds, a list of conditions to fulfill for the JOIN. They are in the same syntax as the single parameter variant of Db_Query->where (both the string and array variants), which means that it will be identifier protected if it is a plain string (provided Db_Query->escape is set to true).

The third parameter is the names of the columns to select. By default Db_Query_Select->join selects all columns ($columns = false), but by sending other values it is possible to select some or none (use an empty array for no columns). $columns will be sent to Db_Query_Select->column (as the first parameter), which means that they can also be aliased or controlled by escaping.

And lastly we have the $type parameter which will determine what type of JOIN will be performed. This string will be uppercased and put before "JOIN" in the query (NOTE: It won't be validated, so do not use data from the user without strict validation).

example.title: Joining tables

section.title: No escape() and join()
section.para: The parameters affected by Db_Query->escape are $condition and $columns. $columns will behave just like the first parameter of Db_Query_Select->column and $condition behaves just like the first parameter of Db_Query->where.

section.title: Filtering columns aggregated by GROUP BY (ie. using HAVING)
section.para: To add a having clause to the query, use Db_Query_Select->having:

The first parameter is never identifier protected, nor is it escaped. This is because the filter used in HAVING is often an aggregate function, such as SUM or MAX. $condition will also be filtered for "or" in the beginning of the string (just like the OR filtering of Db_Query->where).

If $value is null, then the $condition will be appended to the HAVING clause. But if this parameter is not null it will be escaped (provided Db_Query->escape is true, default) and concatenated with $condition (if the $condition does not have a comparison operator, "=" will be added between the condition and the value).

section.title: Grouping rows (GROUP BY)
section.para: To add columns to the GROUP BY clause, use Db_Query_Select->groupBy:
The $columns is identifier protected and is then added to the array.

$table and $table_is_aliased controls wether to add a table alias in front of the columns (ie. "table_alias.column"). $table is the table alias, and will be prefixed with the database prefix if $table_is_aliased is false.

section.title: Issuing a COUNT() query
section.para: COUNT() queries are quite common, hence were the Db_Query_Select->count method created. It temporarily modifies the current query object, making it count the number of rows instead of fetching a result set.

By default, count sends a "COUNT(1)" query, which counts all rows in a result set. This might not be satisfactory, so the $column parameter is there to replace the "1" within the COUNT() function (you can also add multiple columns by separating them by commas), $columns will be identifier protected.
false can be returned in case of an error.

example.title: Couning a query and then fetching the data

section.title: Getting the result
section.para: To get the result, use the Db_Query_Select->get method:

example.title: Getting results from a select query
example.programlisting:
$q = Db::getConnection()->select();
$r = $q->from('tracks')->get();

section.title: INSERT Queries
section.para: For the INSERT query objects, Db_Query_Insert, the table to insert the data into is already specified. So the only information that needs to be added to the object is the data to insert.

section.title: Adding data to insert
section.para: To add data to the insert object, use Db_Query_Insert->set:

The first variant enables you to add an array with data (column => value) which is merged into the current data contained in the object. The second variant just sets a single value to the value of $value.
If $value (or the value of an associative array) is a Db_Query_Select object, then that query will be incorporated as a subquery.

warning.para: The subquery must only select one column, otherwise the database will raise an error.

section.title: Inserting multiple rows simultaneously

warning.para: This might not be supported in all database servers, check if your database is supporting the correct syntax before use.

section.para: RapidDataMapper has support for multi-row insertions by using the method Db_Query_Insert->add to add additional rows:
This adds another internal row, which means that all subsequent calls to Db_Query_Insert->set will populate the new row.
The $data parameter is sent to Db_Query_Insert->set if it is populated (after the new row has been created).

section.title: Db_Query_Insert and no-escape
section.para: If Db_Query->escape is set to false, then the Db_Query_Insert->set method will not escape the $value, instead it will just be concatenated into the VALUES part of the INSERT query.

note.para: Db_Query_Insert does not inherit from Db_Query as it does not need the majority of the functionality.

section.title: UPDATE Queries
section.para: This object is just like the Db_Query_Insert objects, already pre-populated with the table to store the data in (made by Db_Connection->update). The greatest difference between the Db_Query_Insert and Db_Query_Update is that Db_Query_Update inherits from Db_Query; making it inherit all Condition creating methods.

section.title: Setting data
section.para: The Db_Query_Update->set method works just like the equivalent method found in Db_Query_Insert:
The exception is that Db_Query_Update does not have an Db_Query_Insert->add method. This means that the Db_Query_Update->set method always add the data to the same "row".

section.title: Limiting the updates
section.para: Limiting is made by calling the Db_Query_Update->limit method:
The $limit parameter contains the maximum number of rows that will be allowed to be modified by the query.

section.title: Filtering what to update
section.para: Db_Query_Update inherits all the filtering methods from Db_Query, see SQL Conditions on how to add conditions to the query.

section.title: Issuing an UPDATE query
section.para: Just as with INSERT queries you use the Db_Query_Update->execute method:

section.title: Updating multiple tables in a single query

warning.para: This might not be supported in all database servers, check if your database is supporting the correct syntax before use.

section.para: To update multiple tables, pass an array of table names as the second parameter to Db_Connection->update.

example.title: Updating multiple tables in one query

warning.para: If you have columns which are identically named in two or more of the tables you are updating you have to prefix each of the columns with the table name in the calls to Db_Query_Update->set.

section.title: DELETE Queries
section.para: The Db_Query_Delete object is already pre-populated with two things when you get it from Db_Connection->delete: tables to delete from and their aliases.

section.title: Adding another table to delete rows from
section.para: To add another table to the query you can either use Db_Query_Delete->from or Db_Query_Delete->join:
The Db_Query_Delete->join and Db_Query_Delete->from work just like their Db_Query_Select counterparts, with the exception that they cannot select columns.

These two methods will only add the table(s) to the query, but they will not have rows removed from them. This is useful when you need to filter by a relation or some other value which is not located in the table from which the rows should be deleted.
To make the delete query also remove rows from one or several of the added tables, use Db_Query_Delete->addDelete:
The contents of the $tables parameter is added to the list of tables/aliases to delete rows from.

warning.para: Not all databases support multi-table deletes.
Check with your database's manual before using them.

section.title: Limiting the delete query
section.para: Limiting is made by calling the Db_Query_Delete->limit method:
The $limit parameter contains the maximum number of rows that will be allowed to be deleted by the query.

section.title: Filtering what to delete
section.para: Db_Query_Delete inherits all the filtering methods from Db_Query, see SQL Conditions on how to add conditions to the query.

section.title: Issuing a DELETE query
section.para: Just as with INSERT and UPDATE queries you use the Db_Query_Delete->execute method:

section.title: Controlling escaping
section.para: By default are all the data sent into the query builders either escaped or identifier protected. To control escaping Db_Query and all its descendants has the Db_Query->escape:
Db_Query->escape will return the object it is located on, which means that if it is called on a Db_Query_Select object, that object instance will be returned.
The setting that Db_Query->escape controls does not affect previous calls to the query object, so if you want to disable escaping for some parts and not for others, it is definitely possible.

example.title: Switching escaping on and off during construction of a single query

section.title: The Different SQL Conditions
section.para: Conditions are very common in SQL, and it is almost impossible to avoid them. As soon as you need to filter something you have to use them (unless you want to do it the slow way: load everything and then iterate in PHP).

RapidDataMapper provides helper methods on the query objects to make it easy to both create the initial conditions but also to simplify the addition of extra conditions. The conditions do not have to be specified all at once, instead you can add them wherever the need arises.
The code below dynamically adds a LIKE condition to a query when it is a "search request":

example.title: Adding additional WHERE conditions

section.title: Replacing AND with OR boolean operators
section.para: All the conditions have their methods on the query building objects (except for INSERT which does not have the need) and the first parameter behaves the same on all of them: It is identifier protected and if it is prefixed by an OR ("or ") then an OR operator will precede the condition instead of an AND.
If there are no earlier conditions no boolean operator will be prepended, even if you explicitly write "or " before the column name.

example.title: Using OR operators

section.title: WHERE
section.para: The WHERE condition is the most commonly used and also the one with the most features in the query builder. It can add the conditions in sequences, but it can also nest them in parenthesis and use subqueries.

By default all the conditions and values sent to Db_Query->where will be identifier protected and escaped, respectively. The identifier protection will protect all the identifiers (to avoid both injection attacks and interference with database keywords) but it will preserve all conditional operators (eg. "=", "<", ">", "!=").
To avoid escaping or identifier protection, use Db_Query->escape to temporarily switch escaping off.
Function synopsis for Db_Query->where:

section.title: Nesting WHERE conditions
section.para: The first and second variants creates a nested list of conditions that will be wrapped in parenthesis. If the first parameter is empty (first variant), it will be preceded by AND if there are conditions before it. If the first parameter is equal to "or" (second variant) it will instead be preceded by OR.
You can not only use Db_Query->where in the nested query (on the nested where object), but also Db_Query->whereIn, Db_Query->whereNotIn and Db_Query->like.

example.title: Using nested WHERE conditions

section.title: Conditions between two columns
section.para: The third variant is a lot simpler, it will simply append the $condition to the WHERE stack (but it will still parse the OR condition if present, and also protect the identifiers provided escaping is on):

example.title: Adding conditions between different columns

section.title: Conditions between column and a value
section.para: To add a condition which compares a column with a specified value, you just supply a column name as the first parameter ($condition, with optional comparison operator) and the value to compare with as the $value parameter.
If the $condition does not have a condition at the end, an equal sign ("=") will be appended. The check for a boolean OR operator will also be made (see Replacing AND with OR boolean operators).

If Db_Query->escape is set to false, $condition will not be identifier protected (conditions will still be appended and OR will also be parsed, and if a condition is missing at the end of $condition, an "=" will still be appended) and $value will be concatenated (no escaping) and then appended to the WHERE stack.

example.title: Comparing column to a value

section.title: Condition with a subquery
section.para: You can also make a condition that compares a column to a single value returned by a subquery (notice: SINGLE value, otherwise it is a high probability that the database will complain).
It will work the same as if you compare a column with a value, only that the value is substituted with the subquery.

example.title: Comparing a column with a subquery

section.title: WHERE IN
section.para: The WHERE IN condition matches a single column against a list of values, matching if the column matches at least one of the values. The WHERE IN condition is added to a query by calling Db_Query->whereIn:
As usual you can prepend an or to the column to concatenate it with an OR to the previous condition.

example.title: Using WHERE IN with a PHP array
Using subqueries with WHERE IN

section.para: If the Db_Query->escape method has set escaping to false, $column will not be identifier protected (but "OR " is still parsed).

example.title: Using WHERE IN without escaping the column

section.title: WHERE NOT IN
section.para: This is a variant of the WHERE IN condition, but instead of searching for matches to the supplied list it searches for columns NOT matching the list.

section.title: LIKE
section.para: To add a LIKE search condition, use Db_Query->like:

The $column parameter is filtered for "or " and also identifier protected. $match is escaped, with the addition that LIKE wildcards also are escaped (eg. in MySQL are "%" and "_" escaped), to prevent a too high workload on the server.
The $side parameter dictates on which side the "%" wildcards should be placed ("%" matches any number of characters of any type). The possible values are "left", "right" and "both".

example.title: Using Db_Query->like

section.title: WHERE IS (NOT?) NULL
section.para: To filter by the presence of a value in a column (ie. if it is null or not), use Db_Query->whereIsNull:
This will add a IS NULL condition based on $column to the WHERE part of the query (the "OR" filter still applies on $column).
The $yes parameter is there to tell if whereIsNull should check for null or the absence of null.
This variant just adds a IS NOT NULL condition, behaves exactly like Db_Query->whereIsNull with $yes set to true.

section.title: Fragments with parameters added to WHERE
section.para: Sometimes you would like to add a large prewritten condition (or list of conditions) to the WHERE part of the query, but still be able to escape all the values. RapidDataMapper provides a way for you to do that, where it only replaces certain placeholders with the escaped values. This is also called prepared statements with bound parameters.
(Actually, it is not, but it works exactly like it on the PHP side.)

This works like the $binds parameter to Db_Connection->query, with the exception that it only appends it to the WHERE part of the query. It also parses any prepended "or " on the $condition parameter.

example.title: Using bound parameters in the WHERE part of a query builder
